Another technique is to work with advisory groups*
Perhaps adult education specialists can heIn NAEB members
learn how best to organize and work with advisory groups
in (1) identifying adult education interests and needs in
their station’s service area; (2) determining the objectives
of the programs which they select to serve those interests
and needs; (3) planning the content and format of the selected
programs; and (4) evaluating the effectiveness of the programs
in meeting those interests and needs. It might be mentioned
that one possible weakness with advisory groups in the past
has been the failure to include prospective listeners in
their membership*
Relationship of Radio and TV in a University
Ohio State University has applied for a television
license* Much planning has preceded its application. Much
more planning will be needed before OSU can establish and
put a television station into operation, assuming a tele¬
vision license is issued. It is to be expected that re¬
sponsible OSU officials would appreciate receiving information
which would help them in the establishment and operation of a
TV station.
We at WOSU assume that our primary responsibility is to
extend the services of the university to adult Ohio listeners.
Should this also be the chief concern of the television sta¬
tion or should the TV outlet be used primarily as a training
laboratory for students aspiring to find work in television?
